If I married and changed my surname to that of my spouse, I have to get a copy of my marriage license in addition to everything else and go through a lengthy process of updating *all of my documentation* before I can vote.  If I've been adopted by a step-parent and taken that person's surname, same thing applies.  It's a big deal because a hundred million people could be disallowed the right to vote, based purely on *manufactured technicalities specifically designed to prevent voters from voting*.  It's called voter suppression.  And it *sucks*.  It's wrong in every way and on every level, an underhanded way for corrupt politicians to secure their offices by pretending that people simply don't exist.  It violates both the spirit of the Constitution and the letter of the law, but, like gerrymandering, it's a tactic that hasn't been ruled illegal (yet).

Comment: It's not about the right to *use* a name, it's about the right to vote after changing a name.  Under this legislation, a person who's name differs from the name on the birth certificate, for any reason, is ineligible to register for voting until or unless the name change is demonstrated to be valid and certified.  The legislation requires the voter to go through multiple extra steps prove that the person who was born with one name is still the same person after changing that name, if the person wishes to register to vote.  Per this legislation, after changing a name, the person is no longer a legally existing entity until additional documentation re-establishes that person's identity to prove that the person who was born is the same as the person who stands in front of the registrar.  84% of all married women would be ineligible to vote under this legislation (79% change their surname to that of their spouse, 5% append their spouse's surname to theirs with a hyphen) unless they obtain copies of their birth certificates and marriage licenses, go to courthouses, fill out paperwork, pay fees, and replace ***all of their existing identification with new identification***.  *And* acquire a passport, if they didn't already have one, or perform the same process to update the passport.  Almost 60,000,000 women forced to jump through hoops to vote.  And that's just married women.  There are roughly 5,000,000 adopted U.S.-born children in the U.S., and \~4 million step-children.  A good portion of those use the surnames of their legal guardians and would be disenfranchised by this legislation in the same way married women would.  The passport requirement is even less sensible, not only because many people in the U.S. don't have passports, but also because an immigrant is *more* likely to have a passport than American citizens in certain demographics.  Approximately 80% of African-Americans don't have passports, versus nearly 50% of the immigrants, foreign visitors and students, and migrant workers who have passports.  Furthermore, all of the documentation shown to obtain a passport is already required in order to obtain a valid state ID or driver's license (which, as i corrected you in a previous response, is not the same as the identification issued to immigrants), so requiring a passport is equivalent to saying, "Prove you are who you say you are *again*, because the previous proofs which are still valid and legally acceptable are being questioned".  And all of this is unnecessary because **our court system already keeps records of these things**.  There's no justification for requiring a person who's changed his/her name to present five forms of documentation in order to vote when **all of that documentation is already on file and verifiable**.  The one thing you've said that I agree with is that it's nonsense, because it *is* nonsense, but it's nonsense imposed on voters by a group of people **intentionally trying to prevent certain demographics from voting**.  It's legislative gerrymandering.  It's not to verify citizenship, because citizenship is already verifiable and 100% verified at several steps along the way, it's a deliberate attempt to disenfranchise people who will not vote according to a preferred outcome.  To *restrict voting amongst the eligible population* so the results of voting can be controlled.  To use your own example, people who live in gerrymandered districts don't "lose their right" to use their address, but they do lose the right to *vote in the district that existed before it was gerrymandered*, and they also have to re-register to vote because their districts were changed.  Same bullshit, different way to impose it on voters.
